question: Question_05_(a)
sols:
We wish to maximize the value of \emph{$f$(x,y,z) = z} subject to the
constraints

\begin{align*}x + y + z = 2, \quad x^{2} + y^{2} + z^{2} = 2.\end{align*} So we use Lagrange
multipliers. The objective function, $\Lambda$, is

\begin{align*}\displaystyle \Lambda(x,y,z,\mu,\nu) = f(x,y,z) + \mu(x + y + z - 2) + \nu(x^{2} + y^{2} + z^{2} - 2)\end{align*}
Computing the partial derivatives of $\Lambda$ with respect to all the
variables \emph{x, y, z} and the Lagrange multipliers $\mu,\nu$ and
setting them equal to zero gives:

\begin{align*}
(1) \quad \frac{\partial \Lambda}{\partial x} &= \mu + 2\nu x = 0 \\
(2) \quad \frac{\partial \Lambda}{\partial y} &= \mu + 2\nu y = 0 \\
(3) \quad \frac{\partial \Lambda}{\partial z} &= 1 + \mu + 2\nu z = 0 \\
(4) \quad \frac{\partial \Lambda}{\partial \mu} &= x + y + z - 2 = 0 \\
(5) \quad \frac{\partial \Lambda}{\partial \nu} &= x^{2} + y^{2} + z^{2} - 2 = 0\end{align*} To begin with, we observe that \emph{ν} can not be zero,
because if it was, then equations (1) and (2) would force \emph{μ = 0},
while equation (3) would force \emph{μ = -1}; a contradiction. Hence, we
combine equations (1) and (2) to see that the maximum of \emph{$f$} occurs
on the plane \emph{y = x}:

\begin{align*}\begin{cases}
\mu + 2\nu x = 0 \\
\mu + 2\nu y = 0
\end{cases} \quad \rightarrow \quad y = x\end{align*} Taking this result and using
(4), we find

\begin{align*}2x + z - 2 = 0 \quad \rightarrow \quad x = \frac{2 - z}{2}\end{align*} Taking
these two results and using (5) we have an equation for \emph{z}:

\begin{align*}x^{2} + y^{2} + z^{2} - 2 = \left(\frac{2 - z}{2}\right)^{2} + \left(\frac{2 - z}{2}\right)^{2} + z^{2} - 2 = 0\end{align*}
Multiplying this equation by 4 and expanding all the quadratic terms we
get:

\begin{align*}\displaystyle 8 - 8z + 6z^{2} - 8 = 6z^{2} - 8z = 0\end{align*} Solving this
equation for z we get

\begin{align*}\displaystyle z = 0,\ \frac{4}{3}.\end{align*} Taking the larger of the two
results we obtain the maximum of f(x,y,z) = z subject to the given
constraints which is \emph{z = 4/3}.
